awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Nanoparticle Growth from Anthropogenic Volatile Organic Compounds (AVOC) during CLOUD11
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will enable participation in the CLOUD11 field campaign that will take place at the CLOUD chamber facility at CERN in Geneva Switzerland (Sept - Nov 2016).  The CLOUD facility is unique because of its cleanliness, unique control over a wide range of environmental conditions, demonstrated ability to realize experimental conditions that closely resemble those found in the atmosphere, and access to a large array of state-of-the-art instrumentation provided by the Science team to study gas- and aerosol composition at the molecular level.  The broader impacts of this research include improved knowledge about the sources of aerosols relevant to air quality and climate.         

The CLOUD11 field campaign has the following objectives: (1) Conduct nucleation experiments of anthropogenic volatile organic compounds (AVOC); (2) Conduct nucleation experiments involving biogenic volatile organic compounds (BVOC); and (3) Conduct experiments that focus on OH radical initiated oxidation of AVOC and BVOC, and varying concentrations of SO2, NOx, NH3, and relative humidity (RH).  This research supports the deployment of a CE-DOAS instrument to measure glyoxal and methylglyoxal, major first generation oxidation products from aromatic AVOC.  This effort includes the investigation of the "salting-in" of volatile (and soluble) molecules as a mechanism to overcome the Kelvin effect towards the efficient growth of neutral stabilized nanoclusters. A systematic study of RH driven "salting-in" in context of nanocluster growth holds potential as a "probe" to trace how much water is associated with nanoparticles and whether they can grow to sizes where they can act as cloud condensation nuclei (CCN) influencing the formation of clouds.

por.por_cntn:
New particles form as the result of the chemical transformations of vapors in the atmosphere. The growth mechanisms of nanoparticles are currently not well understood. However, initial clusters of molecules can grow nanoparticles efficiently in urban air, where volatile organic compounds from anthropogenic sources (AVOC) are abundant. Also biogenic organic vapors (BVOC) and inorganic material (e.g., iodine from oceans) can grow nanoparticles. Without material to grow nanoparticles to larger sizes, small particles are rapidly lost due to coagulation (collisions between particles). The competition between coagulation and growth mechanisms determines whether nanoparticles can grow to larger sizes and act as cloud condensation nuclei (CCN, 50nm or larger), affect cloud formation, cloud lifetime, and the efficiency of clouds to reflect radiation back to space (Earth albedo). If breathed in, nanoparticles further penetrate deep into our lungs, and have been measured in cells where they cause adverse effects on human health.

This project provided unique opportunities for three CU graduate students to investigate the chemical mechanisms by which organic vapors and iodine grow nanoparticles at the CLOUD facility at CERN, Geneva. CLOUD is a unique facility to conduct simulation chamber studies on the formation and growth of nanoparticles, because of its cleanliness, unique control over a wide range of environmental conditions, demonstrated ability to realize experimental conditions that closely resemble those found in the atmosphere, ability to study ion-induced nucleation, exhibit charge control, and access to a large array of state-of-the-art instrumentation provided by the Science team to study gas and aerosol composition at the molecular level. For the first time, relative humidity (RH) was varied systematically in CLOUD experiments to resemble the urban atmosphere, and investigate whether the condensed aqueous phase participates in the mechanisms by which organic vapors grow nanoparticles. The students deployed Differential Optical Absorption Spectroscopy (DOAS) to demonstrate first glyoxal measurements at CLOUD. Glyoxal is a highly oxygenated molecule (HOM) that reacts with water on aerosol surfaces, and adds to the growth rate of nanoparticles, e.g., by forming complexes of glyoxal hydrate with sulfate ions, among other products. These measurements help to constrain numerical model simulations to assess the contributions of reactive uptake to measured growth rates of nanoparticles. DOAS measurements of other small molecules, namely nitrogen dioxide (NO2) and iodine (I2), were used for actinometry studies to characterize the upgraded light system at CLOUD, assess chamber homogeneity, and to provide independent constraints to the calibration of mass spectrometers. These experiments provide important pre-requisite information to develop the photolysis module of the University of Colorado box-model, and conduct numerical simulations that inform the chemistry by which organic vapors and iodine can grow nanoparticles in urban air, forests, and in the marine coastal atmosphere.
